tit.e: Junshaku (To promote a kurodo (Chamberlain) working over six years from the sixth rank to the fifth rank)

sen.j: 巡爵（じゅんしゃく）とは平安時代初期に成立した蔵人の叙位に関する慣例。
sen.e: Junshaku is a customary practice of conferring a Court rank on kurodo, which developed in the early Heian period..

sen.j: 巡爵とは、太政官において式部・民部・外記・史記など特定の部署に属する六位の官人の中から、1人を年労即ち在職年数に応じて毎月正月の除目において従五位に叙爵することをいう。
sen.e: Junshaku is promoting one of the government officials of the sixth rank belonging to the divisions of Shikibu, Minbu (popular affairs), Geki (Secretary of the Grand Council of State) or Shiki to Jugoi (Junior Fifth Rank), in accordance with the tenure (the number of years in service), at Jimoku (ceremony for appointing officials) performed by Daijokan (Grand Council of State) on every new year's day.

sen.j: 殊に巡爵の事例としては、蔵人所における六位蔵人の巡爵がよく知られる。
sen.e: Junshaku of government officials of the sixth rank at Kurododokoro (the Chamberlain's office) is a well-known case of Junshaku.

sen.j: 年労第一の蔵人即ち極臈が毎年叙爵に預かったとされ、叙留即ち留任の例外を除き、大概は国司に転じたという。
sen.e: It is said that kurodo with the longest tenure, in other words gokuro, was ennobled every year with the exception of the cases where the kurodo was allowed to remain in office (joryu), and that most of them made the transition to kokushi (provincial governors).

sen.j: 蔵人で巡爵に預かった者は殿上を退き、蔵人五位といわれ巡任に預かったとされる。
sen.e: Promoted kurodo is said to have left the court and assumed the position of Kurodo no goi.

sen.j: なお、殿上を退くことをよしとしない者はあえて叙爵を受けず、六位に留まり、改めて最末席の蔵人となった。
sen.e: Those who decided not to leave the court made a point of not being ennobled in order to remain at the sixth rank, and restarted a career as kurodo at the lowest rank.

sen.j: こうした、「鷁退（逆退とも。げきたい）」という慣例が生まれたという。
sen.e: Thus, the custom of gekitai (that the sixth rank kurodo declines the peerage and get demoted to Shinkurodo in order to remain as Tenjobito) sprang up.
